docs.snippet: The space race rode a sustained burst of federal research dollars. What could propel an "energy race"?...
docs.lead_paragraph: This is a quick addendum to the previous post exploring what it would take for a president to pursue meaningful climate and energy policy in a multitasked world. One approach, hinted at by Senator Barack Obama off and on, is an Apollo-scale investment in advanced energy technology. The chances of a quick push of this sort are poor given the state of the economy, but what would a "Moon shot" for energy look like?
docs.abstract: The space race rode a sustained burst of federal research dollars. What could propel an "energy race"?

headline.main: What Would an Energy 'Moon Shot' Look Like?

docs.snippet: Penn State Coach Joe Paterno, who once took the national stage for the Republicans, did not endorse a candidate this time around....
docs.lead_paragraph: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. - Joe Paterno is best known for being Penn State's coaching icon in black Nike sneakers and chunky glasses. So when he was asked for his take on the presidential election, it might have seemed like a strange question for a college football coach.
docs.abstract: Penn State Coach Joe Paterno, who once took the national stage for the Republicans, did not endorse a candidate this time around.

docs.snippet: At several polling places throughout New York City, long lines and heavy turnout were reported....
docs.lead_paragraph: Overview, 10:13 p.m. | Lines were long at many -- but not all -- polling places across the five boroughs today, with reports of voting machine and registration problems. Read related New York region election posts on City Room. Click here to refresh this post and scroll down for more polling place reports and photos. Local readers are encouraged to post their own voting reports in the comments below.

headline.main: Long Lines at Many New York Polling Places

docs.snippet: Forget exit polls -- Twitter and YouTube let you find out what's going on with individual voters....
docs.lead_paragraph: For those who are clicking from FiveThirtyEight to Politico to Drudge and back again vainly searching for fresh information on Tuesday's elections, there's good news: Web sites like Twitter and YouTube are providing real-time updates from the polls, voter by voter. And Google offers a window into our collective interests by showing what the world is searching for right now.
docs.abstract: Forget exit polls -- Twitter and YouTube let you find out what's going on with individual voters.

headline.main: Taking the Digital Pulse of Voters, One at a Time

docs.snippet: INTERACTIVE: ELECTION GUIDE 2008     Everything needed to navigate Election Day: a look at the candidates and where they stand on the issues; videos of advertisements, speeches and debates; and interactive breakdowns of the electoral map and the b...

docs.snippet: Voter registration problems are particularly difficult for the city's thousands of voters who have changed their names with their sex....
docs.lead_paragraph: Polling place foul-ups are not uncommon. But advocates say they are too common among a certain set of voters: transgender people who have changed their first names to match their new sex. Voter registries often carry the transgendered voter's birth name, which doesn't match their newly adopted names. As a result, many of these voters are turned away at the polling place and often shy away from trying to correct the problem immediately and cast their votes, said Michael Silverman, executive director of the Transgender Legal Defense & Education Fund, in Manhattan. Mr. Silverman estimated that there are "tens of thousands" of transgender people in New York City and that many will have problems voting because of problems with mismatched names.
docs.abstract: Voter registration problems are particularly difficult for the city's thousands of voters who have changed their names with their sex.

headline.main: Fighting for the Rights of Transgender Voters
